Package com.apps.util

Class Prompter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apps.util.Prompter
  • public class Prompter
extends java.lang.Object

    General-purpose prompter mechanism that delegates to a java.util.Scanner, which must be provided in the constructor. The Scanner passed to the constructor must be initialized by the client, and allows for console-based or file-based input.

    Console-based input would typically be used for running the actual application. File-based input can be used to automate unit testing without human involvement. 

     
     // To use with a human user at the console:
     Prompter prompter = new Prompter(new Scanner(System.in));

     // To facilitate automated unit testing without human involvement:
     Prompter prompter = new Prompter(new Scanner(new File("responses.txt")));
    Version:
    1.1
    Author:
    Jay Rostosky

    • Constructor Detail

      • Prompter

        public Prompter​(java.util.Scanner scanner)
        Creates a Scanner-based prompter object, that delegates to the Scanner for all input. All input is read (and returned) as a single line of text.
        Parameters:
        scanner - delegate object used by this prompter for reading input.

    • Method Detail

      • info

        public java.lang.String info​(java.lang.String info)
        Outputs the provided text, followed by a newline. Simply calls System.out.println(info).
        Parameters:
        info - informative text to show the user, not a prompt message.
        Returns:
        the provided text - most applications will ignore this return value.

      • prompt

        public java.lang.String prompt​(java.lang.String promptText)
        Prompts for input, and returns the line of text entered, as a string.
        Parameters:
        promptText - prompt message.
        Returns:
        the line of text that was input, as a string.

      • prompt

        public java.lang.String prompt​(java.lang.String promptText,
                               java.lang.String pattern,
                               java.lang.String errorText)

        Prompts for input, validates it against the regex pattern provided, and returns the line of text entered, as a string. If the input does not match the pattern, the error text is displayed, and then the prompt text is displayed again. The input is validated against the regex pattern via String.matches().

        The prompt text and error text are output verbatim, exactly as provided. To add a blank line or two between the user input line, the error message line, and the follow-on user prompt, just include "\n" in the errorText value, as appropriate. For example: 

         
     prompter.prompt("Please enter your age: ", "\\d+", "\nThat is not a valid age!\n");
        Parameters:
        promptText - prompt message.
        pattern - regex pattern, used to validate the input string.
        errorText - error message displayed when input string does not match regex pattern.
        Returns:
        the line of text that was input, as a string.
